I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1  In  February  2014,  the  Office  of  the  Council  of  Ministers  (OCM)  asked  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) for technical assistance (TA) to support the national rollout of a 
regulatory impact assessment (RIA) program to the executive government commencing in 2015. 
In response, ADB conducted a fact-finding mission in June 2014; during that mission ADB and 
the OCM agreed on the proposed impact, outcome and outputs, implementation arrangements, 
cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference.1 The government’s planned rollout of the 
RIA program to 23 line ministries builds on the OCM’s experience in piloting RIA in seven line 
ministries  from  2010  to  2014  with  ADB  financing.2 The  TA  will  support  13  of the  23  line 
ministries during the rollout phase. Previous consultations on plans for a national rollout were 
held on an intermittent basis from February 2013 to February 2014, and these consultations 
benefited from  previous  grant  implementation review  missions.  The  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
2.  ADB  has  had  a  long  engagement  with  the  OCM  on  developing  RIA  practice.  The 
proposed TA follows on from the grant attached to subprogram 2 of the Promoting Economic 
Diversification Program (footnote 2). The grant funded the RIA pilot project and the capacity 
development under the grant project has provided OCM staff and the seven pilot ministries with 
a strong understanding of, and practice in, the basic analysis necessary for carrying out RIAs. 
The grant project is expected to be financially closed by July 2015. ADB is also supporting RIA 
programs  in  the  Lao  People’s  Democratic  Republic  and  the  Philippines,  following  similar 
institutional structures as described in para. 5. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Cambodia continues to reform its economy to raise competitiveness for private sector 
development.  Improving  the  quality  of  regulation  making  is  central  to  the  government’s 
economic and governance reform agenda. While there have been successful reforms in sectors 
such as enterprise law, the licensing and permit requirements for doing business in Cambodia 
are substantial and impose a burden on investors and small and medium-sized enterprises in 
particular. 
 
4.  In 2010, ADB carried out a survey of 180 enterprises in four Cambodian provinces to 
collect data on licensing requirements and associated business costs as part of the monitoring 
and evaluation framework of the government’s RIA reform. The survey revealed the following 
features: (i) time costs involved in preparing applications and waiting for the license were the 
major costs of business regulation, accounting for 69% of total costs incurred by enterprises in 
2010 (Figure 1a); (ii) business costs of regulation were most burdensome on microenterprises 
and  small  firms  (Figure  1b),  which  explains  why  small  firms  are  mostly  unregistered;  (iii) 
business costs of regulation were especially high in manufacturing (Figure 1c); and (iv) business 
compliance costs varied by type of license (Figure 1d). 
 
5.  The  Government  of  Cambodia  is  currently  piloting  an  RIA  project  as  one  of  its 
approaches to addressing the high cost of doing business in Cambodia. The pilot project is 
expected to be completed in the first quarter of 2015. The RIA program aims to help the 
government improve the quality of regulation making by following a systematic regulatory review 
process, including an assessment of the net benefits of the regulation to the economy. A

6.  The RIA system being piloted by the OCM draws on international practice. It includes the 
establishment of the ORIA within the Economic, Social and Cultural Council (ECOSOCC) in the 
OCM, which champions the RIA initiative in government, produces RIA guidelines, monitors 
participating ministries’ compliance with RIA guidelines, provides training and other capacity 
development activities to the ministries, and is responsible for public awareness and education 
on good practice regulation. Each participating line ministry is responsible for (i) carrying out 
RIA on a selection of existing or proposed regulations or bills and (ii) submitting these with the 
draft regulations to the concerned minister as part of the decision-making process. The main 
objectives of the RIA system are to enhance transparency in the regulation-making process, 
and to promote a more systematic way to assess the impact of regulations and consultations for 
improved decision making. 
 
7.  Under the pilot project much progress has been made in building capacity of staff at the 
ORIA and at the seven participating line ministries. As of 31 May 2014, 22 RIAs had been 
completed and posted on the ECOSOCC website.4 Another eight are in progress and are

expected to be completed in December 2014. In terms of outcome, there is evidence that the 
RIAs have helped to modify regulatory proposals to ensure the costs of regulations are reduced; 
in some cases the RIAs recommended no regulatory intervention. There is evidence that the 
RIA system has helped improve stakeholder consultations, the quality of the regulation, and 
business community support for the regulation when stakeholders are engaged early in the RIA 
process.5 
 
8.  There are challenges to making RIA sustainable in the Cambodian government: (i) the 
pilot project is based on voluntary participation of the ministries, and, while appropriate for a 
pilot, it does not always solicit collaboration from non participating agencies even within the 
ministries due to its voluntary nature; (ii) sufficient budget resources to fund RIA activities in the 
ministries and develop a critical mass of RIA practitioners in government, academia, and the 
private sector are necessary for sustaining RIA; and (iii) there is a need to ensure private sector 
participation  through  public  consultations,  ensure  an  available  pool  of  private  sector  RIA 
practitioners, and develop private sector capacity to self-regulate when regulatory options are 
unfeasible or costly.6 
 
9.  The OCM recognizes these challenges and also the potential benefits from using RIA to 
improve regulatory quality across the government. The OCM is therefore drafting a royal decree 
to mandate the use of RIA in government. The royal decree will convert the ORIA into the 
permanent Office of Best Practice Regulation (OBPR) inside OCM, and the decree will require 
23 ministries and their attached agencies to adopt RIA in a phased rollout from 2015 to 2018. 
The rollout will start in 2015 with the current seven ministries plus three additional ministries. 
The  mandatory  RIA  system  will  require  all  ministries  to  produce  RIAs  for  all  draft  bills, 
subdecrees, and implementing regulations. Following the structure of the pilot project, each 
ministry will be required to set up an RIA unit and designate an RIA focal person and team of 
RIA practitioners to be trained. 
 
10.  The TA will support the OCM in the initial stages of the national rollout of an RIA system 
covering 13 line ministries (i.e., the seven line ministries currently piloting RIA, an additional 
three line ministries in 2015, and three more line ministries in 2016). It is expected that the 
government will partially fund the 2017 and 2018 RIA expansion. The TA will primarily focus on 
capacity building and on-the-job training of regulators at the additional participating ministries. 
Innovative  modes  of  delivery  of  capacity  development  will  be  included,  such  as  use  of 
international  resource  persons  for  training,  partnerships  with  local  universities  for  training, 
secondments  for  high-performing  RIA  practitioners  to  offices  of  best  practice  regulation  in 
overseas jurisdictions, and competitive grants to the private sector for carrying out regulatory 
reviews in collaboration with line ministries. In addition, the proposed TA will focus on RIA 
monitoring and annual reporting on regulations by the OCM through the new OBPR. 
 
11.  The TA supports the governance and private sector development pillars of the country 
partnership strategy, and the TA is aligned with the government’s national sector priorities of 
improving  governance  and  private  sector  development  through  improving  the  quality  of 
regulation  making.7 The  government  is  committed  to  RIA  reform.  The  Prime  Minister  has

III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  The  impact  will  be  reduced  costs  of  business  regulatory  compliance,  with  target 
indicators measuring the reduction in the costs associated with regulatory compliance. The 
outcome will be quality of laws and regulations improved, with target indicators measuring 
Cambodia’s  ranking  in  global  surveys  on  regulatory  quality  increasing  by  15  places,  the 
increase in the average length of public consultations per regulation, and the increase in the 
number of stakeholders included in public consultations. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
13.  The key activities are divided into three outputs. 
 
14.  Output  1:  Capacity  development  of  staff  at  the  new  Office  of  Best  Practice 
Regulation. Once approved in early 2015, the royal decree will convert the ORIA into the 
OBPR, a permanent office within the ECOSOCC of the OCM. The OBPR will oversee the rollout 
of RIA and ensure RIA compliance. Capacity development of OBPR staff will include staff 
training on RIA, writing techniques for regulatory impact statements, qualitative and quantitative 
analysis, secondments to overseas offices of best practice regulations, enhancements to the 
OBPR’s  existing  information  technology  system  for  tracking  RIA  progress  among  the  line 
ministries, and production of annual reports on regulation. The OCM will also review the existing 
legal framework for industry self-regulation with a view toward developing this approach as an 
alternative to government regulation. 
 
15.  Output 2: Capacity development of staff in 13 line ministries. Each line ministry will 
set up an RIA unit and designate a focal person and staff to become RIA practitioners. Thus, 
capacity  development  activities  will  include  staff  training  on  RIA,  writing  techniques  for 
regulatory impact statements, development of questionnaires and survey sample frames, basic 
qualitative and quantitative analysis, and stakeholder assessments.  
 
16.  Output 3: Public outreach on regulatory impact assessment. This output will focus 
on public education on good regulation making, development of a pool of RIA practitioners in 
the private sector and academia through training and competitive research grants, and the 
nurturing of civil society groups and private sector and industry bodies to work with the OCM on 
being advocates for good practice regulation. 
 
17.  There are two assumptions for effective implementation of the TA: (i) macroeconomic 
conditions remain stable, and (ii) Cambodia continues its commitment to implement reforms to 
improve competitiveness. There are four risks to effective implementation of the TA: (i) some 
ministries may resist carrying out RIAs on proposed legislation and regulations, which has been 
documented in other countries during the early stages of a rollout; (ii) there are insufficient 
budgetary resources to fund and staff the RIA units; (iii) the issuance of the royal decree could 
be  delayed;  and (iv)  a  lack  of  staff  capacity may  slow  implementation  of  the  RIA rollout. 
Measures to mitigate these risks include (i) the draft royal decree’s provisions for national 
budget support to ministries implementing RIA, and (ii) the TA’s focus on capacity building and

5 
training of staff. Partnering with local universities with courses on regulation would also support 
longer term development. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $850,000, of which $800,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF).  The  government  will  provide 
counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office space, and other in-kind contributions.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  The executing agency will be the ECOSOCC of the OCM, which is responsible for 
impact assessments of laws and subdecrees. The ORIA (later converted to OBPR) within the 
ECOSOCC will oversee implementation of RIA activities. The implementing agencies will be 
comprised of the seven line ministries implementing RIA (footnote 3) plus an additional six 
ministries to be determined after the royal decree has been approved. The ORIA (through the 
ECOSOCC) will provide office space with furniture and support services for the consultants. 
 
20.  Two international experts (for a total of 22 person-months) and three national experts 
(for a total of 38 person-months) will be engaged to implement TA activities.8 The international 
experts are (i) an RIA expert (4 person-months) to provide strategic and advisory support to 
ORIA staff, and (ii) a finance officer (18 person-months) to manage procurement of equipment 
and accounts under the TA. The three national experts are (i) a cost–benefit analysis expert (10 
person-months) to provide training to RIA practitioners on qualitative and quantitative analysis; 
(ii) an information technology expert (10 person-months) to enhance the existing ECOSOCC 
website and intranet for tracking RIA documents within the government; and (iii) a project officer 
(18 person-months) to manage day-to-day operations of the project office. In addition, the TA 
will engage up to seven international resource persons to train ORIA and implementing agency 
staff on specialized topics related to policy development and RIA. The selection and recruitment 
of consultants and resource persons will be conducted in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). TA proceeds will be disbursed in 
accordance with the ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended 
from time to time). Equipment such as computers and office equipment for the six ministries 
joining the rollout for the first time and for the newly created OBPR will be procured under this 
TA following ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2013, as amended from time to time), and the 
assets will be handed over to the executing agency upon completion of the project. 
 
21.  Following the signing of the TA agreement between the government and ADB, the TA 
will  be  implemented  over  24  months  from  January  2015  to  December  2016.  Consultant 
deliverables are included in the terms of references in Appendix 3. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Cambodia for the National Rollout of the Regulatory Impact Assessment in 
Government, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
8  To reduce administrative burden and improve economy and efficiency and value for money, some of the consulting 
services under the TA will be engaged on output-based (lump-sum) contracts.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  A team of two international consultants (for a total of 22 person-months) and three 
national  consultants  (for  a  total  of  38  person-months)  will  be  recruited  by  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  through  individual  contract  services  to  implement  technical 
assistance (TA) activities. The selection and recruitment of consultants will be conducted in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time).  TA  proceeds  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB's  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).1 Equipment procured under this 
TA will be procured following ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2013, as amended from time to 
time) and the assets will be handed over to the executing agency upon completion of the project. 
 
2.  Regulatory impact  assessment  expert (international, 4 person-months). The team 
leader will provide capacity development support to the staff of the Office of Best Practice 
Regulation  (OBPR)—currently  called  the  Office  of  Regulatory  Impact  Assessment—in  RIA 
practices, advocacy, and training. She or he must have an economics degree or equivalent and 
at least 10 years’ professional experience in an office of best practice regulation or equivalent. 
The tasks of this assignment include (i) providing capacity development training to OBPR staff; 
(ii) supporting OBPR with training and capacity development of staff from the 13 ministries 
required to carry out regulatory impact assessments (RIAs); (iii) assisting OBPR staff in working 
with academic institutions to oversee the design of a course on the economics of regulation; and 
(iv) providing OBPR and the Economic, Social and Cultural Council (ECOSOCC) with strategic 
and policy advice on RIA rollout. The expert will report to the OBPR director and the ADB 
project officer. 
 
3.  Finance officer (international, 18 person-months). The officer will be responsible for 
managing  project  accounts,  including  procurement  of  supplies,  arrangement  of  workshop 
venues, and recording of and financial reporting on project expenditures. She or he will provide 
capacity building training to OBPR accounts staff on the management of budgets and ADB 
procurement  rules.  She  or  he  must  have  an  accounting  degree  and  at  least  5  years  of 
professional accounting experience. She or he should be a chartered accountant, and will report 
to the OBPR director and ADB project officer. 
 
4.  Cost–benefit expert (national, 10 person-months). The expert will provide training to 
OBPR  staff,  line  ministries,  and  academia  on  cost–benefit  analysis  (CBA)  and  qualitative 
techniques  and  tools.  She  or  he  must  have  an  economics  degree  and  at  least  3  years’ 
professional experience specializing in CBA tools and techniques. Specific tasks include (i) 
developing  training  materials  for  CBA  and  qualitative  techniques,  including  designing 
questionnaires and surveys, selecting sample frames, etc.; (ii) carrying out training of RIA staff 
in the 13 line ministries on survey design and implementation, CBA, and qualitative techniques; 
(iii) providing guidance and supervision to RIA staff in the 13 line ministries on carrying out CBA 
on selected regulations; and (iv) working with the OBPR director to develop a CBA module for 
the economics of regulation course. She or he will report to the OBRP director and the ADB 
project manager. 
 
5.  Information  technology  expert  (national,  10  person-months).  The  information 
technology expert will be responsible for enhancing the existing ECOSOCC website, which is

draft RIA documents is located. She or he must have an information technology degree and at 
least 5 years of experience in website design and development, and development of intranet

6.  Project officer (national, 18 person-months continuously). The project officer will be 
responsible  for maintaining  project  accounts  and  procurement  of  supplies  and  helping  the 
finance officer provide support to the ECOSOCC on budget planning and account recording. 
She or he will be responsible for arranging project logistics, team and mission appointments, 
workshop and conference venues, etc. She or he will work closely with and report to the finance 
officer. 
 
7.  Resource persons (seven international, maximum 10 days effort each). The project will 
engage through invitation up to five international experts to prepare and present materials 
during project-related training and public advocacy seminars, workshops, and conferences. 
Training should be used as input for drafting regulatory impact statements. The expertise of the 
various resource persons will be determined in consultation with the OBPR counterpart and 
could include resource persons who can provide assistance with specific regulatory topics, 
writing  techniques  for  drafting  regulatory  impact  statements,  and  survey  designs,  among
